title: Syllabus
text:
Course Description
This course introduces psychology majors to modern data science tools and techniques using R and the tidyverse. Students will learn to import, tidy, transform, visualize, and communicate data effectively. The course emphasizes practical skills for working with real psychological data, reproducible research practices, and creating publication-ready visualizations.

title: Syllabus
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Import and tidy data from various sources (CSV, Excel) into analysis-ready formats
Transform data using dplyr verbs (filter, select, mutate, summarize, join)
Create effective visualizations using ggplot2, applying principles of visual perception and design
Conduct exploratory data analysis to understand patterns and relationships in data
Produce reproducible reports using Quarto that integrate code, results, and narrative
Communicate findings through well-designed figures that tell a clear story

R: Download from cloud.r-project.org
RStudio Desktop: Download from posit.co/downloads

title: Syllabus

Knaflic, C. N. (2015). Storytelling with Data: A Data Visualization Guide for Business Professionals. Wiley.

title: 4: Data Transformation II
text: Content for Wednesday, April 8, 2026

title: 4: Data Transformation II
text:
Before class
üìñ Readings:

R4DS Ch 3: Data transformation (section 3.5)
R4DS Ch 4: Workflow: code style

title: 4: Data Transformation II
text:
During class
We‚Äôll cover:

group_by() ‚Äî define groups for operations
summarize() ‚Äî calculate summary statistics
Combining group_by() + summarize() for grouped statistics
count() ‚Äî a quick shortcut for counting
Code style best practices
Building complete analysis pipelines


Slides

   View slides in new tab


   Download PDF



Embedded slides

title: 4: Data Transformation II
text:
After class
‚úÖ Practice:
Using the flights dataset:

Calculate the average departure delay by carrier
Find which carrier has the most flights
Calculate the percentage of flights that were delayed (arr_delay > 0) by month
Find the top 5 destinations with the highest average arrival delay
Create a complete pipeline that filters, groups, summarizes, and arranges







NoteThe power of group_by()



group_by() doesn‚Äôt change how your data looks ‚Äî it changes how other verbs work on it. Think of it as setting up the ‚Äúbehind the scenes‚Äù grouping structure.
data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarize(mean = mean(score))



Psychology application
# Calculate descriptive statistics by condition
experiment_data |>
  group_by(condition) |>
  summarize(
    M = mean(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    SD = sd(score, na.rm = TRUE),
    n = n()
  )

Before class
üìñ Reading:

R4DS Ch 1: Data visualization

title: 2: Your First Visualization
text:
During class
We‚Äôll cover:

Why visualize data? (Anscombe‚Äôs Quartet)
Introduction to ggplot2
The grammar of graphics: data, aesthetics, geoms
Aesthetic mappings (color, size, shape)
Faceting for small multiples
Themes and labels


Slides

   View slides in new tab


   Download PDF



Embedded slides

title: 2: Your First Visualization
text:
After class
‚úÖ Practice:

Create at least 3 different plots using the mpg dataset
Try different geoms: geom_point(), geom_bar(), geom_histogram(), geom_boxplot()
Experiment with mapping different variables to color, size, and shape
Use facet_wrap() to create small multiples
Save your favorite plot using ggsave()







NoteThe ggplot2 template



ggplot(data = <DATA>, mapping = aes(<MAPPINGS>)) +
  <GEOM_FUNCTION>()
This simple template can create almost any visualization!

title: 1: Introduction & Setup
text:
After class
‚úÖ Complete these tasks:

Make sure R and RStudio are installed and working
Create a new RStudio Project called ‚Äúpsy410‚Äù
Install the tidyverse package: install.packages("tidyverse")
Run library(tidyverse) and make sure it loads without errors
Try glimpse(mpg) to see your first dataset!







TipGetting help



If you run into installation issues, check out R4DS Chapter 8: Workflow: getting help or post in our class discussion forum.

title: 3: Data Transformation I
text: Content for Monday, April 6, 2026

title: 3: Data Transformation I
text:
Before class
üìñ Reading:

R4DS Ch 3: Data transformation (sections 3.1‚Äì3.4)

title: 3: Data Transformation I
text:
During class
We‚Äôll cover:

Introduction to dplyr
filter() ‚Äî pick rows by their values
arrange() ‚Äî reorder rows
select() ‚Äî pick columns by name
mutate() ‚Äî create new columns
The pipe operator (|>)


Slides

   View slides in new tab


   Download PDF



Embedded slides

title: 3: Data Transformation I
text:
After class
‚úÖ Practice:
Using the flights dataset from the nycflights13 package:

Filter to flights departing in December
Find all flights to Los Angeles (LAX)
Create a new variable for flight speed (distance / air_time * 60)
Select only the carrier, origin, destination, and your new speed variable
Arrange by speed to find the fastest flights







TipKeyboard shortcut



The pipe (|>) is so common that there‚Äôs a keyboard shortcut:

Windows/Linux: Ctrl + Shift + M
Mac: Cmd + Shift + M




Installing the flights dataset
install.packages("nycflights13")
library(nycflights13)

title: 5: Data Tidying
text: Content for Monday, April 13, 2026

title: 5: Data Tidying
text:
Before class
üìñ Reading:

R4DS Ch 5: Data tidying

title: 5: Data Tidying
text:
During class
We‚Äôll cover:

What is tidy data? The three rules
Wide vs.¬†long format
pivot_longer() ‚Äî wide to long
pivot_wider() ‚Äî long to wide
Extracting information from column names
separate_*() and unite() for splitting/combining columns


Slides

   View slides in new tab


   Download PDF



Embedded slides

title: 5: Data Tidying
text:
After class
‚úÖ Practice:

Take this wide dataset and make it tidy:

wide_data <- tibble(
  participant = c("P1", "P2", "P3"),
  pre_test = c(45, 52, 48),
  post_test = c(62, 58, 71)
)

Practice with survey data ‚Äî pivot questionnaire items from columns to rows
Create a summary table and use pivot_wider() to format it nicely
Use separate_wider_delim() to split a column like ‚Äúage_gender‚Äù into separate columns







ImportantThe three rules of tidy data




Each variable is a column
Each observation is a row
Each value is a cell

When your data follows these rules, tidyverse tools (ggplot2, dplyr) work seamlessly!



Common patterns in psychology data
Repeated measures:
# Wide (common in SPSS)
data_wide <- tibble(
  id = 1:3,
  time1 = c(50, 55, 48),
  time2 = c(55, 58, 52)
)

# Tidy version
data_wide |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = starts_with("time"),
    names_to = "time",
    values_to = "score"
  )
Questionnaire items:
# Calculate scale scores from long format
survey |>
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("bdi_")) |>
  group_by(participant) |>
  summarize(bdi_total = sum(value))

title: Schedule
text:
Week 8: Storytelling with Data

Monday, May 18






WarningNo Class








Session 15: Storytelling with Data
Wednesday, May 20
Drawing from Knaflic‚Äôs ‚ÄúStorytelling with Data‚Äù

Understand the context ‚Äî Audience, message, and the Big Idea; 3-minute story; storyboarding
Choose appropriate visuals ‚Äî Review: continuous ‚Üí line/scatter; categorical ‚Üí bars; avoid pies, 3D, dual axes
Eliminate clutter ‚Äî Gestalt principles; strategic contrast; alignment and whitespace
Focus attention ‚Äî Preattentive attributes (color, size, position); ‚ÄúWhere are your eyes drawn?‚Äù test
Think like a designer ‚Äî Visual affordances and hierarchy; accessibility; colorblind-friendly palettes

üìñ Read: R4DS Ch 11: Communication
